chunks.en: I'd like to ask how to connect the network cable crystal head wire sequence?

The wiring module made by the decoration company is connected like this, it doesn't seem to be the common T568A/B wire sequence:
 https://i.imgur.com/mYDtpYq.jpeg

The decoration company didn't make the crystal head on the other end of the weak current box, I bought a crimping tool and wanted to crimp the crystal head myself. I'd like to ask, which wire sequence should I use?
The module wire sequence and the crystal head are different, and they will all be marked. For example, the AB columns in your picture, this module is connected correctly, it is T568B.

@mzname Because the internal wiring of the module is particular, it needs to be anti-interference, it's not just a direct connection with copper wires. The wiring designs of each module are different, so the wire sequence is also different.
https://img.gdsz.net/i/2024/02/11/12k3ggd.jpgT-568B, connect according to the picture
@bao3 Evasive and avoiding the substantive issue
@Tumblr Oh, so the crystal head should be connected according to the standard T568B, right?
Usually it's B, the picture is correct

chunks.en: @lyizhuo Connect the module according to the colors marked on the module itself, the wire sequence will be adjusted by the module itself, don't overdo it. The four pairs of wires inside the network cable are arranged clockwise in sequence, so it's easiest to crimp the crystal head with the B type wire sequence. For cables like Cat6a, you can only crimp with the b type wire sequence if you want to do it correctly, I have tried a type and it's almost impossible. The actual measurement shows that swapping the positions of the four pairs of colors 12, 36, 45, and 78, swapping the positions of two wires of the same color, does not affect the use at all, does not affect the network speed, and there is no additional interference, so there is no need to recrimp. If they are not swapped in pairs and the different colors are mixed up, it will seriously affect the network speed.
Itâ€™s connected correctly, itâ€™s 568b, you can also connect your network cable according to the standard 568b, but to add one thing, the way this decoration company connected it have some issues
I followed the module's wire sequence to crimp the crystal head at first ğŸ˜­ it seems like I can only cut it off and redo it
@txydhr I followed the module's wire sequence to crimp the crystal head at first ğŸ˜­ it seems like I can only cut it off and redo it

Incorrect wire sequence doesn't necessarily mean it can't be used, some wires don't need to be connected in the first place, and the router will automatically reverse the wires that must be connected if there are any errors.

chunks.en: Straight-through cables have B wire sequence on both ends, crossover cables have A wire sequence on one end and B wire sequence on the other end
The module has already marked the B type sequence, just follow that sequence and crimp, don't follow the crystal head's method to crimp the module

A bloody lesson: a few days ago, I found that the order of the network cable panel and the crystal head was very different. I followed the crystal head's order to crimp the network cable, but it didn't work in either direction [bitter]. Later I thought about trying to crimp according to the order on the panel (the same as the picture of the OP), and it worked instantly. After reading the above comments, I finally understood that the panel and the crystal head were indeed that different. Can any expert explain why?ğŸ˜‚
Connect it according to how the module is labeled, the internal wiring of the module is not necessarily what you imagine
@lyizhuo Actually you don't need to, try it, it's just that the wire pairs are reversed internally, it doesn't affect usage.
@txydhr I will try connecting the fiber optic cable later, if it doesn't work, I will cut the exposed wires in the weak current box, which I have almost cut off ğŸ˜‚
I also recently learned that the wire sequences of the modules are all messed up

It should be said that the colors are only for people to distinguish, in fact, as long as the wire sequences match on both ends. So it is possible that the wire sequence is correct, and the colors used are the installer's own habits
@bao3 You are just talking nonsense
